==[[:Traveling around colombia]]== {| cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" style="border: 1px red solid; background: #ffffcc; width: 95%; margin: auto; color: #000000;" | style="width: 40px; text-align: center;" | [[Image:Stop hand nuvola.svg|30px]] | delete. Copyright infringement issues were unresolved. [[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 04:49, 20 November 2008 (UTC) |- | colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px red dashed;" | There is no official policy in Wikibooks against travel brochures but then, I don;t think this material is relevant for Wikibooks. Rather, I feel it should be moved to [[w:Wikitravel|Wikitravel]] [[User:Ravichandar84|Ravichandar]][[User talk:Ravichandar84|My coffee shop]] 07:36, 19 October 2008 (UTC) : [[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''Comment''' Since this book was nominated for inclusion discussion, issues have been raised to whether the book is in violation of source material copyright. Contributors have already copied in GFDL material (which has subsequently been deleted) and much of the material seems to be copied in from outside sources, all without attribution. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 02:52, 28 October 2008 (UTC) ---- :[[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''Comment''' If it is keep it needs to be Wikified badly. [[User:Zginder|Zginder]] ([[User talk:Zginder|talk]]) 19:05, 19 October 2008 (UTC) :[[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''Comment''' The problem with a transwiki to Wikitravel is that the licenses aren't compatible. Wikitravel uses the Creative Commons Attribution ShareAlike license rather than the GNU Free Documentation License. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 20:05, 19 October 2008 (UTC) ::[[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''Comment''' [[w:Wikitravel|Wikitravel]] is not a part of [[w:Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia Foundation]], I guess. Are you sure a trans-wiki is allowed in this case?-[[User:Ravichandar84|Ravichandar]][[User talk:Ravichandar84|My coffee shop]] 04:52, 21 October 2008 (UTC) :::Sorry I never replied to this, but since the licenses aren't compatible the need to address the problem of technical possibilities is bypassed. In any case I think if they are using Wikimedia software transwiki should be possible... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 04:20, 28 October 2008 (UTC) This wikibook is a work by a group of students that need the opportunity to create something new. The space is in construction yet and they are reading a lot to reach the level of a speace like this, so considere the deletion please. Thanks.—Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Dyayis|Dyayis]] ([[User talk:Dyayis|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Dyayis|contribs]]) 09:06, 20 October 2008 :[[Image:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep''' This might eventually develop into something, so I say let it incubate. It should be moved to [[:Traveling around Colombia]] though. --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|talk]]) 12:51, 20 October 2008 (UTC) See below. :[[Image:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep''' and rename per Jomegat. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 13:47, 20 October 2008 (UTC) :[[Image:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' - while this could be fixed, this just a copy/paste job from a translation tool (e.g., [[Traveling_around_colombia#Amazon_region|here]] and [http://web.minambiente.gov.co/biogeo/menu/biodiversidad/regiones/amazonia/amazonas.htm here]. While I can't say the whole book is subjected to this type of infringement, it's probably a safe bet given the poor markup.--[[User:Retropunk|Retropunk]] ([[User talk:Retropunk|talk]]) 16:28, 22 October 2008 (UTC) ::The second link for the comparison isn't up. I have always thought copyvios should be addressed outside of VfD. If it's a copyvio it will be deleted, that shouldn't be an argument for the VfD. Copyvios are a process on their own, above community decisions. (ie: we can't decide to keep a copyvio). --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 18:23, 22 October 2008 (UTC) ::: I checked the second link again, and it appears to be up. It's in Spanish.--[[User:Retropunk|Retropunk]] ([[User talk:Retropunk|talk]]) 00:02, 23 October 2008 (UTC) :::: Indeed, it's up now and that section is a direct translation of that text. From "The Amazon basin is characterized..." to "... a large loss in the biodiversity" they even include the url (I only noticed that now that I was checking the texts, on the other hand translations in several copyright laws are treated distinctly (in this case the original rights is what matters, we have also to take in consideration that it is a .gov site and it may be into the public domain). The options are to check the right to have it here, a deletion of that section or a rewording/restructure of it, the text is very small. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 00:27, 23 October 2008 (UTC) ::::: Before I [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Traveling_Around_Colombia&diff=1312091&oldid=1312081 removed] it, there was also a good amount of stuff copied directly from Wikipedia without citation. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 02:18, 23 October 2008 (UTC) :::::: Wouldn't adding the citation be better than removing the content? The project seem to have several editors working on it, this would address future additions, we could also add information on how to request a transwiki into the project discussion page. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 02:46, 23 October 2008 (UTC) ::::::: I don't think so. These editors don't seem to be thinking about anything other than cramming as much material on the page as possible. The Wikipedia text was just copied from a rendered page, rather than wikimarkup. I replaced it with a link to the Wikipedia page. I have yet to see this book show any promise under the current team. Future editors now have access to the latest version of the material on Wikipedia. ::::::: Adding instructions on the talk page is a good idea. If you think it's worth your time, please do. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 03:59, 23 October 2008 (UTC) :::::::: Just stating for the record that I have done the deed :) and that the book has been active recently. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 18:49, 25 October 2008 (UTC) :: It appears that http://www.lablaa.org is a big source of the editors information, which may or may not be a free source. There's a few paragraphs added by [[User:Orinoquian region|Orinoquian region]] that appear to be direct translated copy/paste. There appears to be some minor markup, but not a lot.. mostly bold tags. And there's some references, but I don't know where they were copied from. Additionally, it looks like someone removed all of the major [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Traveling_Around_Colombia&diff=1312091&oldid=1312081| copyediting ] that [[User:Swift|Swift]] did. In fact, since Swift's edits, this PAGE has grown from 80k to over 130k. --[[User:Retropunk|Retropunk]] ([[User talk:Retropunk|talk]]) 09:15, 26 October 2008 (UTC) :[[Image:Symbol keep vote.svg|15px]] '''Keep''' this project is being developed by students, we will correct the errors this week, for this reason we need that this page not erase it, the information of the orinoquian region comes from the library luis angel arango and the information is of books of the library. the idea is that the students that are work in this wikibook they can correct errors they find among their information.—Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Orinoquian region|Orinoquian region]] ([[User talk:Orinoquian region|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Orinoquian region|contribs]]) 04:35, 27 October 2008 :: While there seems to be some copyediting to the book, the potential copyvios are still there. A translation is probably a derivative work, and while you can put a derivative work into the public-domain if the original work is in the public domain, you can not put a derivative work into the public domain while having the original work copyrighted. The work-around for this is to cite/reference the material. However, you're going to have huge blocks of citations for portions of the book, which is not the original thought of citation. I'm not sure what the copyright laws are in Colombia, so someone else would need to speak for this. If you can provide a link from the Luis Angel Arango Library that states the material is copyright/public-domain, or otherwise free resource, then you can copy it/translate it directly. However, to me, there's a lot more than the "Orinoquian Region" section that just screams "I've been copied from another source." --[[User:Retropunk|Retropunk]] ([[User talk:Retropunk|talk]]) 21:47, 26 October 2008 (UTC) :[[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''Comment'''the copyright of the Luis Angel Arango Library specify that the information can be used if it is not for profit or commercial, yet I ask for a permission to publish the text in Wikibooks, they replied that I had no problem with this, as long as I placed the reference and quote the author of the work. -- [[User:Orinoquian region]] ([[User talk:Orinoquian region|talk]]) 28 October 2008 ::The not for profit or commercial can't be guaranteed by the Wikibooks license. See if you have a writen consent (email is ok) from the copyright holder, it may not be the same as the author... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 00:52, 28 October 2008 (UTC) : [[Image:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' While I think this topic can fit within the scope of Wikibooks, I find there are great problems with how the import of material has been handled. The material seems to come largely from third party sources rather than being original works of the editors. While some text is being modified, it is still derivative work. I think that at this point we are faced with two alternatives. :# The editors go through the entire edit history, and identify the source for every text import. :# Delete the book and start over. : Since there are layers of edits and text has been split up and altered, were there any copyright violations, they would be very painstaking to remove. For that reason, I recommend that the book contributors save whatever original work they have to their user (sub-)page(s) and we delete this book. Since much of it is from external sources, the material shouldn't be too difficult to re-import. : This may sound harsh and like a lot of work, but I think that at this point it may be less work. Unless we see a detailed description of where the material is from and how it is permitted to be published at Wikibooks, we have to delete this book. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 02:52, 28 October 2008 (UTC) : [[Image:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' I was unaware of the copyvios when I originally voted "keep". --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|talk]]) 03:39, 28 October 2008 (UTC) : [[Image:Symbol delete vote.svg|15px]] '''Delete''' I agree with Swift in the best solution approach to the myriad of problems that have been pointed out so far. Since we are working preemptively it makes the move to the users space a possible solution so to preserve translations and access provenience. If editors elect to proceed on that path I call attention to the above post by [[User:Retropunk|Retropunk]] in that regard. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 04:20, 28 October 2008 (UTC) *It is a community contribution construction, so the invitation is for all to participate in the improvement of this space.—Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:69.79.176.92|69.79.176.92]] ([[User talk:69.79.176.92|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/69.79.176.92|contribs]]) 09:42, 29 October 2008 : [[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''Comment''' I've placed a note on [[Talk:Traveling_Around_Colombia#Possible_copyright_violations|the talk page]] and contributors' talk pages (even IP addresses, since there were quite a few) alerting the book contributors to the recent discussion. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 01:02, 30 October 2008 (UTC) :{{keep}} Improvements need to be made but being a travel guide isn't enough to warrant deletion. I wish we supported more travel books here at Wikibooks. Wikitravel is a commercial website and there are many people out there who don't want anything to do with a for-profit educational website.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:30, 16 November 2008 (UTC) : [[Image:Symbol comment vote.svg|15px]] '''comment''' I was just about to close this as delete when I saw your vote. I, too, initially leant on the keep side with the argument that it was within the scope of our project. In subsequent edits, a trend of copyright violations emerged. I don't see how we can still keep this book in light of that. --[[User:Swift|Swift]] ([[User talk:Swift|talk]]) 01:15, 17 November 2008 (UTC) |}

Layout for each lesson :* Dialogue (by posters, conversations, or whatever.) :* Discussion of Vocabulary in Dialogue :** Discuss various uses of vocabulary if necessary (e.g., politeness) :** Optional links to dialogues for previously learned vocabulary :* Grammar :** Discuss grammar points, giving more examples if necessary. :** Link to previous grammar points (maybe by categories) :* Optional Quick Review :* Optional link to Wikiversity for practice work.

{{recipesummary|Beverage recipes|8-10 servings|prep: 12.5 hours|1}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Beverages|Beverages]]
'''Coffee concentrate''' is produced through the '''cold brew''' method, in which ground [[cookbook:Coffee|coffee]] is soaked in water for several hours, then strained, leaving a strong coffee liquid. Coffee made from coffee concentrate is generally less acidic than regularly brewed coffee and can be prepared stronger or weaker per the individual drinker's taste. It can be kept refrigerated for two to three weeks.
==Ingredients== * 1 pound ground coffee OR coffee and [[cookbook:chicory|chicory]] blend * 3.5 quarts mineral water * 2 1 gallon jars * sieve * cheese cloth
==Procedure== # Add coffee grounds to jar. # Pour mineral water over grounds, stirring only to ensure all coffee is wet. # Let mixture stand for 10-12 hours (best to let it sit over night). # Line sieve with cheesecloth and place or hold over other jar. Pour coffee mixture into sieve, allowing grounds to collect. # Discard coffee grinds and store coffee concentrate in the refrigerator. It will keep for two to three weeks. # To prepare coffee from concentrate, use a ratio of concentrate:water of 1:2 or 1:3 depending on taste.

page.title: Structural Biochemistry/DNA recombinant techniques/Artificial Chromosomes/Bacterial Artificial Chromosomes (BAC)

revision.text:
==Bacterial Artificial Chromosomes (BAC)== Bacterial Artificial Chromosome also known as BAC is a vector used to clone a target DNA piece and planted in bacterial content. Vectors are carriers that are also made of DNA. The vector acts as a parent host, which much acts like a guide to carry out the gene from cloning. Bacterial artificial chromosomes can be as large as insects. In order to amplify a gene, DNA sequence must be extracted from a desired source using restriction enzymes to cleave the vector and the target DNA and attach into a host bacterium. Plasmids of bacteria usually play a vital role in the cloning process since they are also made of DNA and they can be compatible with experimental gene. Vectors also contain the origin of replication where replication begins at the vector site and proceed with the attached sample. [[Image:BACs_cloning_vectors_Chem114A.jpg]] ==Common Gene Components== ''oriS, repE•F''
 * replicates plasmid replication and regulates copy number
''parA and parB''
 * partitions F plasmid DNA into daughter cells during division and ensures stable maintenance of the BAC
''A'' selectable markers
 *because some BACs also have lacZ at the cloning site for blue/white selection, this is used to resist antibiotics
''T7 and Sp6''
 *phage promoters for transcription of inserted genes
==Contribution to Models of Disease== ===Inherited disease=== BACs are being greatly used in modeling genetic diseases in order to study their effects in the experimentation on transgenic mice. Because complex genes often have many regulatory sequences upstream of the encoding sequence, including many promoter sequences that will control a gene's express level, BACs have been found very useful in this area of study. When tested with mice, BAC has been able to help with the study of neurological diseases, such as Alzheimer's disease or Down syndrome. BAC has also been recently used to study specific oncogenes, which are associated with various different cancers. BAC is transferred over to these genetic disease models through the use of electroporation/transformation, which is essentially transfection with a compatible virus or micro injection. BACs have also been used to detect genes or large sequences of interest, and then used to map them onto the human chromosome using BAC arrays. Because this process is able to accommodate much larger sequences without the risk of rearrangement, it is the preferred method of these types of genetic studies and also more stable than other types of cloning vectors. ===Infection disease=== BACs can also act as clones of large DNA viruses as well as RNA viruses. These clones are known as "infections clones," as transfection of the BAC construct into host cells is enough to initiate the viral infection in the host. The infectious property that the BACs contain has aided in the study of viruses such as herpesviruses, poxviruses, and coronaviruses. Using genetic approaches to mutate and transform the BAC while it resides in bacteria, molecular studies of these viruses can be performed. ==References== http://www.scq.ubc.ca/ THE BIG BAD BAC: BACTERIAL ARTIFICIAL CHROMOSOMES {{BookCat}}

page.title: Talk:System Monitoring with Xymon/Administration Guide/Compiling on CentOS

revision.comment: /* a couple of recommended tweaks */ new section
revision.text:
Toward the end of this tutuorial, this line:
"Next we'll want to steal the Hobbit startup script and use it to start Hobbit upon entering run level 3."
scp root@essex.imaginenetworksllc.com:/etc/init.d/hobbit /etc/init.d/hobbit
It asks for the password for root. Without the password, one cannot "steal" that script.
== a couple of recommended tweaks ==
There are two tweaks I had to find my way to as I was following this book:
- on CentOS 6.2 and compiling Xymon 4.3.7, I noted that starting /home/xymon/server/bin/xymonlaunch.sh --debug showed output looking for tasks.cfg in the top-level /etc/ for some reason. I had chosen nothing unusual as I ran ./configure.server before compiling, and the makefile showed no indication of a bad variable being set. I could not find a way around this, so I used the workaround of creating symlink /etc/tasks.cfg pointed at /home/xymon/server/etc/tasks.cfg. This allowed the server to start normally.
- also, for the Apache less-initiated, it was not clear that /home/xymon/ would need to be 755 in order for /home/xymon/server/www/ to be accessible. That kept me puzzled for several hours.

{{prognav|F Sharp Programming|Exception Handling|Classes}} {{fsharpTitle|Operator Overloading}} Operator overloading allows programmers to provide new behavior for the default operators in F#. In practice, programmers overload operators to provide a simplified syntax for objects which can be combined mathematically. == Using Operators == You've already used operators: let sum = x + y Here + is example of using a mathematical addition operator. == Operator Overloading == Operators are functions with special names, enclosed in brackets. They must be defined as static class members. Here's an example on declaring + operator on complex numbers: type Complex = { Re: double Im: double } static member ( + ) (left: Complex, right: Complex) = { Re = left.Re + right.Re; Im = left.Im + right.Im } In FSI, we can add two complex numbers as follows: > let first = { Re = 1.0; Im = 7.0 };; val first : Complex > let second = { Re = 2.0; Im = -10.5 };; val second : Complex > first + second;; val it : Complex = {Re = 3.0; Im = -3.5;} == Defining New Operators == In addition to overloading existing operators, its possible to define new operators. The names of custom operators can only be one or more of the following characters: : !%&*+-./<=>?@^|~ F# supports two types of operators: infix operators and prefix operators. === Infix operators === An infix operator takes two arguments, with the operator appearing in between both arguments (i.e. arg1 {op} arg2). We can define our own infix operators using the syntax: let (op) arg1 arg2 = ... In addition to mathematical operators, F# has a variety of infix operators defined as part of its library, for example: let inline (|>) x f = f x let inline (::) hd tl = Cons(hd, tl) let inline (:=) (x : 'a ref) value = x.contents <- value Let's say we're writing an application which performs a lot of regex matching and replacing. We can match text using Perl-style operators by defining our own operators as follows: open System.Text.RegularExpressions let (=~) input pattern = Regex.IsMatch(input, pattern) let main() = printfn "cat =~ dog: %b" ("cat" =~ "dog") printfn "cat =~ cat|dog: %b" ("cat" =~ "cat|dog") printfn "monkey =~ monk*: %b" ("monkey" =~ "monk*") main() This program outputs the following: 
cat =~ dog: false
cat =~ cat|dog: true
monkey =~ monk*: true
=== Prefix Operators === Prefix operators take a single argument which appears to the right side of the operator ({op}argument). You've already seen how the ! operator is defined for ref cells: type 'a ref = { mutable contents : 'a } let (!) (x : 'a ref) = x.contents Let's say we're writing a number crunching application, and we wanted to define some operators that work on lists of numbers. We might define some prefix operators in fsi as follows: > let ( !+ ) l = List.reduce ( + ) l let ( !- ) l = List.reduce ( - ) l let ( !* ) l = List.reduce ( * ) l let ( !/ ) l = List.reduce ( / ) l;; val ( !+ ) : int list -> int val ( !- ) : int list -> int val ( !* ) : int list -> int val ( !/ ) : int list -> int > !* [2; 3; 5];; val it : int = 30 > !+ [2; 3; 5];; val it : int = 10 > !- [2; 3; 7];; val it : int = -8 > !/ [100; 10; 2];; val it : int = 5 {{prognav|F Sharp Programming|Exception Handling|Classes}}

revision.text:
{{rfd-survived|Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Cannibalism}}
==Merge with When It Hits the Fan==

You need to run big simulations or experiments with many repetitions (e.g. [[w:Bootstrapping_(computing)|bootstrapping]])? Then you need big computational power. You don't want to spend huge money on one big and expensive computer?
There are many computations, called [[w:embarrassingly parallel|embarrassingly parallel]], because each run or iteration is independent from others and in principle all could run in parallel. Therefore, instead of spending huge bucks on a huge machine, you could rather decide on many cheap computers and have them compute in parallel. The computers are connected in a network and run Linux. This is called a beowulf.
In the next chapters we will see an example of some hardware with actual prices (in euros). In subsequent chapters, we will deal with issues of installation and configuration. In the end we come to running processes in parallel using matlab and R.
{{BookCat}}

==Welcome==

Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]]. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:55%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |

Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]].

Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?) |} --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|talk]]) 18:28, 20 November 2008 (UTC) ==Beowulf== BTW, I changed the names of some of the chapter links so that it follows the [[WB:NC|Wikibooks Naming Convention]]. ==Members== #--[[User:CFeyecare|<font face="Kristen ITC" size="3.5" color="crimson">''''' CFeyecare '''''</font>]]<font color = "black"><sup>'''''[[User talk:CFeyecare| Talk!]]'''''</sup></font>[[User:CFeyecare/templates/signature-tracker| ]] 18:45, 20 November 2008 (UTC): founder

'''Argumentation'''
When teaching argumentation, it is important to show practical methods, as this is often an area that confuses students. By showing pragmatic approaches to structuring an argument, students can better articulate their thoughts. Moreover, the skill of argumentation can be applied to other assignments as well, such as the research paper, cause and effect, and compare and contrast.
''The Toulmin method:''
1. Claim
This is the statement the arguer wants the audience to believe. Claims such as “abortion should be protected by the constitution,” “marijuana should be legal for medicinal purposes,” and “the drinking age should be lowered,” are examples of often over-used freshmen argument claims. The claim can serve as a thesis, and it is an essential starting point for any argument paper.
2. Grounds
The grounds, or data, of an argument emphasizes the arguer’s ethos (or credibility). It is imperative to an argument that the grounds be well founded, noncontroversial, and supportive. Claims supported with solid grounds become much stronger. For example, in an argument about lowering the drinking age, saying “my parents told me drinking is bad for you,” is much less effective than saying, “scientists predict .5% of one’s brain cells are lost every time he/she binge drinks.”
3. Warrant
This links the two previous steps. It creates the bridge between the claim and the grounds. Sometimes the warrant is implicit, unstated, or combined with the grounds.
4. Qualifier
This modifies the strength of an argument. Based on what kind of qualifier you choose, your argument becomes more or less believable. For example, the qualifier, “all people who drink become alcoholics,” is so strong of a claim that it becomes unbelievable. Here, if the qualifier is toned-down, the statement becomes more believable: “Some people who drink become alcoholics.”
5. Rebuttal
It is often important to include and possibly debunk rebuttal arguments. For example, saying “despite scientists claim about the effects of drinking on the brain, it has been shown to be no less damaging than using a cell phone,” shows that you can anticipate your critics.
{{BookCat}}

Ok, I started. I'm hoping people can add the following elements: different approaches to argumentation, different styles of organization, and sample argument paper assignment sheets. --Alex
== Topic Ideas ==
Hello! I was thinking about using the Rogerian argument, as well as the Burkean argument as supplements to this page. Additionally, there are several different types of argumentation that students can use. Thus, there are multiple in-class exercises that students can do; they can also try their hand at using the various argumentative techniques for their major writing assignments. If it is acceptable to everyone paying attention to this discussion forum, I would like to make those additions to this page. [[User:MichaelPickar|MichaelPickar]] ([[User talk:MichaelPickar|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/MichaelPickar|contribs]]) 13:41, 25 October 2012 (UTC)

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: Ghz → GHz using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
A lot of attention should be focused on the hardware assembly. There are many tradeoffs and considerations of speed bottlenecks. You should be careful to settle on a vendor with experience, where they can give you good recommendations.
Here is a list of hardware, which we assembled at the artificial olfaction lab at the [http://www.ibecbarcelona.eu/ Institute for Bioengineering of Catalonia]. Prices are as of May 2008 and do not include taxes.
[[Image:Howtobeowulf_rackmounted.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[w:19-inch_rack|rack]] containing a 8 computers, a [[w:KVM switch|KVM]], and a [[w:network_switch|switch]] (behind KVM).]] We bought 8 computers with these parameters: * [[w:Intel Core 2|Intel Core 2]] Duo Quad Q6600 2.4 GHz FSB1066 8MB * Chipset Intel X38 / [[w:List of Marvell Technology Group chipsets|Intel ICH9R]] * 4 GB RAM [[w:DDR3 SDRAM|DDR3]] 1066 (in 2x2Gb). * 2 x PCI Express x16, 1 x PCI Express x1, 2 x PCI-X y 1 PCI * Marvell88E8056 Dual [[w:Gigabit Ethernet|Gigabit LAN]] controller * Realtek ALC882M 7.1 chanels (sound * 6 USB 2.0 ports y 1 IEEE1394 * VGA 512MB [[w:GeForce|Gforce]]8400GS PCI-e * 160 GB de Disco Duro [[w:Serial ATA|SATA II]] 3 Gb. * DVD R/W, Multicard reader/writer * 19" rack computer case, 4U, with frontal lock. * 550W Server Guru
They cost 923 euros each.
In order to operate 8 computers efficiently you need a monitor that you can connect to all machines. Better even a [[w:KVM switch|KVM]] (keyboard video mouse). A KVM with 8 ports cost us 850 euros. The KVM, as the name says, serves as keyboard, monitor, and mouse, and did great service during configuration because it allows fast switching between different computers.
We also need to connect all the computers among themselves: A [[w:network_switch|switch]] with 16 ports, 10/100/1000, comes at 162 euros.
We want to put all the hardware somewhere, where it is save and where it has good conditions of cooling and safety: a [[w:19-inch_rack|rack]] (see picture). The rack on the picture can take up 42 units of 19'' and cost us 500 euros.
Don't be surprised to be charged extra for cables, screws, and multi-outlet power strips. Rails allow you to stack in and take out your computers like drawers. Additional cost: about 700 euros.
Also on top, the VAT, in Spain 18%, which makes about 1500 euros.
Total cost of the beowulf: about 11,090 euros.
In order to connect your computers, you need power lines that can support them. The configuration above needs about 4.5kWatt and we had to wait about 2 months for technicians to fix the capacity (that's Spain).
On the photo you can see the computer hardware mounted into the rack. You can see the 8 computers flanking from two sides the KVM which is in the middle, behind it the switch.
== See also == * [[Computer Hardware]] * [[Switches,_Routers,Bridges_and_LANs]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Installation, Configuration, and Administration

revision.text:
In this chapter, you will find basics of installation, configuration, and administration. Most important here: 1. network setup with DHCP, 2. sharing files over the network with the network file system (NFS). After we cover this, we will come to some more general ideas of administration.
Most beowulfs use a network structure of master (also network head) and slaves, so that computing jobs are going to be distributed from the master to the slaves. All machines of the cluster are connected to the switch. The head will additionally interface with an external network. Master and slaves will share user data over the network. It is easiest to only install the master and one slave (called ''golden slave'') in a first step. In a later chapter we will come to cloning, which is the process of creating machines that are identical to the golden slave. Alternatively to cloning, one may choose to do a diskless boot.
Practically this means, that the master (or head node) has two network interfaces (say eth0, eth1), one connected to the outside world and one connected to the cluster intranet over a network switch. All other computers (the slaves or nodes) are connected to the switch. In order to start processes on the cluster a user logs in on the master and spawns the processes from there to the slaves.
== Outline == *[[/OS and Software/]] *[[/Diskless Boot/]] *[[/Networking/]] *[[/Shared directories and SSH/]] *[[/Miscellaneous/]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Installation, Configuration, and Administration/OS and Software

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: eg. → e.g. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
There are linux distributions specialized on beowulf clusters, such as [http://www.rocksclusters.org Rocks Clusters], which can facilitate the installation and administration of clusters. Unfortunately, rocks clusters (v. 5) didn't recognize the network cards of our computers. We tried the Ubuntu Server Edition (Hardy), which didn't recognize the CD-ROM. [[w:Fedora (operating system)|Fedora 9]] recognized all hardware at once, so this was our distribution of choice.
Linux isn't the only choice, Solaris, AIX, DragonflyBSD, and many more systems have and can be used in clusters. The basic method is the same, often only with minor changes (e.g. Sun Studio instead of GCC).
For master and slaves, we started from vanilla installations.
A selected list of software: * basic gnu toolchain * editors: [[w:Vim (text editor)|vim]], [[w:Emacs|emacs]], [[w:Ed (text editor)|ed]] * [[w:Revision control|version control software]]: [[w:Subversion (software)|subversion]], [[w:Git (software)|git]] * [[w:Secure Shell|openssh]] server+client * [[w:X Window System|X11]] * script languages: [[w:Perl|Perl]], [[w:Python (programming language)|python]], [[w:R (programming language)|R]], [[w:MATLAB|matlab]] * compilers: c/c++, java, fortran, mpicc * sun java * mpich2, pvm
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Installation, Configuration, and Administration/Networking

revision.text:
We want the computers to work in a local network.
The easiest way to setup the network is by DHCP. For practical purposes it is easiest to set up dynamic addresses (DHCP) handled by the master on the basis of physical addresses of slaves' network interfaces. DHCP simplifies the installation of new nodes, because the mac address and hostname is the only thing that is different among the nodes and the DHCP server on the master can manage a new node by a new entry into the configuration file.
In this example we will set up the network IPs to 192.168.1.1 until 192.168.1.8, where 8 is the master.
<source lang="bash"> slave(s):/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0
DEVICE=eth0 ONBOOT=yes BOOTPROTO=dhcp </source>
<source lang="bash"> master:/etc/dhcpd.conf
option subnet-mask 255.255.255.0; option broadcast-address 192.168.1.255; option routers 10.5.170.254; # define individual nodes subnet 192.168.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 { group { # define all slaves, the master (head node) is has a static ip address host node0{ hardware ethernet 00:1E:8C:30:AC:2A; fixed-address 192.168.1.250; } host node1{ hardware ethernet 00:1E:8C:30:B0:A1; fixed-address 192.168.1.1; } #... Here you can put more nodes. Make a list of the mac addresses of all your machines and enter them in the list. } } # ignore petitions from second network interface subnet 10.5.170.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 { not authoritative; } </source>
The idea is to give to slaves the names nodei corresponding to their ip address 192.168.1.i.
Note that the DHCP server provides IP addresses for the other machines not for itself. The master you give a static ip address (192.168.1.250 here). In red hat based distributions this is configured in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 or /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth1.
I configured eth0 for the organization network and eth1 for the cluster intranet. Example files: /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 corresponds to your organization network settings.
<source lang="bash"> DEVICE=eth0 ONBOOT=yes ... </source>
<source lang="bash"> /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth1
DEVICE=eth1 ONBOOT=yes BOOTPROTO=static NETWORK=192.168.1.0 IPADDR=192.168.1.250 TYPE=Ethernet </source>
For the slaves, the interface to the cluster intranet is as follows:
<source lang="bash"> DEVICE=eth0 ONBOOT=yes BOOTPROTO=dhcp NETMASK=255.255.255.0 NETWORK=192.168.1.0 BROADCAST=192.168.1.255 DNS1=... DNS2=... </source>
If you don't use a DNS service on your head you use the DNS service of the network of your organization.
<source lang="bash"> /etc/hosts
127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost ::1 localhost6.localdomain6 localhost6 192.168.1.250 node0 192.168.1.1 node1 # ... add more names of machines here </source>
Note in /etc/hosts that in the loopback line (first line) the hostname is not given in order to avoid problems with message protocols (PVM, MPI).
You need to activate ip forwarding on the head in order to have internet access on all machines. You enable the firewall and include masquerading on the network interface to you cluster. This you do by changing the /etc/sysconfig/iptables file or using some user interface, e.g. system-config-firewall on red hat based systems. Be careful not to make your firewall too restrictive as this can cause problems.
In the /etc/sysconfig/network you need to have: <source lang="bash"> NETWORKING=YES IPFORWARD=YES HOSTNAME=nodei </source>
You have to reinitiate the network services and startup the dhcp server daemon (dhcpd). To have dhcpd startup at boot, in fedora you the ntsysv program allows you to search a list and mark the corresponding entry.
You may want to setup your printers on master and slave (you can copy an existing printer configuration recursively from /etc/cups e.g. from your local office desktop computer).
== Useful references == * [http://tldp.org/HOWTO/Net-HOWTO/ linux networking howto] * [http://tldp.org/HOWTO/DHCP/ linux DHCP howto]] * [http://tldp.org/HOWTO/Firewall-HOWTO.html linux firewall howto]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Installation, Configuration, and Administration/Shared directories and SSH

revision.text:
Now we want to share data among computers. [[w:Network_file_system|NFS]] configuration is remarkably simple (see the linux nfs faq for help). You basically have to install the package, start the nfs services, and change two files.
Let's see the example files:
<source lang="bash"> on the master:/etc/export
/home/ 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0(rw,sync,no_root_squash) /root 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0(rw,sync,no_root_squash) </source>
<source lang="bash"> on the slave(s):/etc/fstab
192.168.1.250:/home /home nfs rw,hard,intr 0 0 192.168.1.250:/root /root nfs rw,hard,intr 0 0 </source>
Sharing /home and /root directories password-less ssh login is simplified. For every user that need access to slaves the following achieves the goal: <source lang="bash"> > ssh-keygen -t rsa confirm choices and leave password empty. > cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub ~/.ssh/authorized_keys </source>
The ~/.ssh/known_host file needs entries for each computer (e.g. by logging in to each machine once). I used option -v with the ssh command to speed up ssh changing parameters in /etc/ssh/ssh_config and /etc/ssh/sshd_config. Options that you might want to specify include protocol 2, port 22, PreferredAuthentications PublicKey, IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa. You might want to turn off checking of .ssh/known_hosts, and on the slaves you might want to ignore the host ip (CheckHostIP no), and turn off any authentication method except for public key and password. One of the fastest cipher methods is RC4 (arcfour in ssh config file)<ref>[http://stateless.geek.nz/2004/10/13/scp-performance/ speed comparison of cypher methods with ssh]</ref>
== External Links == * [http://www.faqs.org/docs/securing/chap15sec122.html SSH server FAQ]]
== See also == * [[SSH]] * [[LPI Linux Certification/Configuring An NFS Server]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Parallelization of computation

revision.text:
As the principal goal of having the cluster is to run programs in parallel on different machines, I installed protocols for message-passing for distributed-memory applications. There are two common ones: the [[w:Parallel Virtual Machine|Parallel Virtual Machine]] (PVM) and [[w:Message_Passing_Interface|Message Parsing Interface]] (MPI).
For scientific computing we can use high-level computing platforms or languages such as C/C++ and fortran. Here we will see GNU R and matlab. R can spawn parallel jobs using either PVM or MPI. Matlab comes with an implementation of MPI (more precisely mpich2).
Note that for PVM you need to enable password-less ssh access (see previous section) from the server to all clients. Also, for PVM, MPI (includes matlab's mdce), the network configuration you have to remove the host names from the loop-back line (where it says 127.0.0.1) of the /etc/hosts file. Just put localhost instead. Then you need a text file with a list of all machines you wish to use for computing and call it pvmhosts and mpihosts.
== Outline == * [[/PVM/]] * [[/MPI/]] * [[/GNU R/]] * [[/Matlab/]] * [[/C/]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Parallelization of computation/PVM

revision.text:
The [[w:Parallel Virtual Machine|Parallel Virtual Machine]] (PVM) allows computers which are connected over a network to be used as a single distributed parallel computer.
Installation of PVM is straightforward from packages, for configuration environment variables need to be set up:
<source lang="bash"> add to /etc/profile:
export PVM_ROOT=/usr/share/pvm3 export PVM_TMP=/tmp export PVM_RSH=/usr/bin/ssh export PVM_ARCH=LINUXX86_64 export PATH=/usr/local/bin/:$PATH </source>
In the pvm environment (which you enter typing 'pvm') after adding your machines you can then try the following and see if you can get a list of your machines.
<source lang="bash"> spawn -> -10 /bin/hostname </source>
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Parallelization of computation/MPI

revision.text:
As for MPI, you can install different implementations.
Compiling and installing [[w:Mpich2|Mpich2]] was very straightforward. The test again as for PVM should be spawning of /bin/hostname. The install guide is a great help in setting up MPICH2.
On the master (node0) you type: <source lang="bash"> mpd & mpdtrace -l </source>
And you should get back the node name (say node0) and port number (say 51227). Then you connect each node to by typing: <source lang="bash"> mpd -h node0 -p 51227 </source>
After this, you can spawn processes with mpiexec: <source lang="bash"> mpiexec -n 10 /bin/hostname. </source>
== See also == * [[Message-Passing Interface/MPI function reference]] * [[Message-Passing Interface]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Parallelization of computation/GNU R

revision.text:
In this section we see an examples of parallelization from within the R computing platform (statistical computing similar to Matlab) using the snow package, which can distribute jobs using either MPI or PVM. In this subsection we will only see usage of R+PVM.
Note, that for installation of packages within R the development packages of R are needed. Anyways, I just installed all R packages that were available in the R repository (something like this: http://cran.es.r-project.org/bin/linux/redhat/fedora9/x86_64, needless to say this may differ for your distribution, machine architecture, and country code).
You need to install R libraries snow and rpvm on master and slave(s). If you don't, R lets you create the PVM cluster object but then freezes when you try to execute a job.
in R: <source lang="matlab"> > library('snow') > library('rpvm') > cl<-makePVMcluster(count=2,names=c('node0','node1')) > clusterCall(cl, function() Sys.info()[c("nodename","machine")]) [[1]] nodename machine "node1" "x86_64"
[[2]] nodename machine "node0" "x86_64" </source>
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Parallelization of computation/Matlab

revision.text:
As for matlab, note that in order to run it on a 64bit system you need shared libraries (on Fedora the package is called libXp, on ubuntu ia32) and some java packages.
Matlab comes with the parallel computing toolbox, the distributed computing server, and an implementation of mpich2. You can find manuals in pdf format on the corresponding mathworks site. You start the mpich2 server as root:
<source lang="bash"> $MATLAB/toolbox/distcomp/bin/mdce start </source>
$MATLAB is the directory of your matlab installation.
(Note: Here holds the same as for PVM. For mdce to work, you need to remove from /etc/hosts the loopback line with your host name in it, i.e. 127.0.1.1 node0 becomes your_network_ip node0. )
We start the job manager: <source lang="bash"> $MATLAB/toolbox/distcomp/bin/startjobmanager -name MyJobManager </source>
Connect one worker: <source lang="bash"> $MATLAB/toolbox/distcomp/bin/startworker -jobmanager MyJobManager -jobmanagerhost node0 </source>
where node0 is the machine where your jobmanager is running (obviously).
...and a second worker on a different machine. From node0:
<source lang="bash"> $MATLAB/toolbox/distcomp/bin/startworker -jobmanager MyJobManager -jobmanagerhost node0 -name worker2 -remotehost node1 </source>
Use the option remotehost to start a worker on a different machine.
Make sure that job manager and workers are running: <source lang="bash"> $MATLAB/toolbox/distcomp/bin/nodestatus </source>
Starting matlab in desktop mode (we need jvm), parallel->configure and parallel->administrate, we choose MyJobManager basically and start the "matlabpool":
<source lang="matlab"> >> matlabpool open </source> You should see the confirmation" Connected to a matlabpool session with 2 labs (or more)."
The simple proof of concept: <source lang="matlab"> >> parfor i=1:5 unix('hostname'); end </source>
== See also == * [[MATLAB Programming]]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Profiling and Benchmarking

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: paralellize → parallelize using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Profiling and Benchmarking/Temperature control

revision.text:
How to check the CPU temperature? <source lang="bash"> > cat /proc/acpi/thermal_zone/THRM/temperature </source>
(you might have different THRM directories for your cores)
If this doesn't work or you want more information, install sensors (in fedora: yum install sensors). You install it by sensors-detect and sensors then prints you information.
<source lang="bash"> > sensors ... Adapter: ISA adapter Core 0: +67.0°C (high = +82.0°C, crit = +100.0°C)
coretemp-isa-0001 Adapter: ISA adapter Core 1: +66.0°C (high = +82.0°C, crit = +100.0°C)
coretemp-isa-0002 Adapter: ISA adapter Core 2: +61.0°C (high = +82.0°C, crit = +100.0°C)
coretemp-isa-0003 Adapter: ISA adapter Core 3: +61.0°C (high = +82.0°C, crit = +100.0°C)
</source>
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Profiling and Benchmarking/Profiling

revision.text:
As a general rule for paralellization: avoid network trafic and access to physical devices. In matlab don't use too much load/save, close, figure, etc.
Useful commands in linux are w, ps, top. W shows you how many users are logged in and what they are doing.
How many matlabs are running? <source lang="bash"> for i in `seq 0 7` ; do ssh node$i "ps aux | grep -i matlab | grep -v helper | grep -v grep" ; done </source>
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Cloning of Slaves

revision.text:
When master and one slave (the '''golden slave''') are installed and configured and now we want to scale up this configuration to more slaves by replicating the exact configuration of the golden slave.
Installing and configuring the OS on each machine manually is cumbersome and prone to error. However, nodes are identical, so why not just copy everything we need? This process is called cloning. We first setup a so-called golden node or model node and then transfer the system to other slave machines. Each new node will come with one new entry in the head node's DHCP server file (/etc/dhcpd.conf) and /etc/hosts file.
For preparation, make sure that in /etc/fstab and in the /boot/grub/menu.lst, there are no physical addresses of hardware (e.g. a hard disk), as they will be different among the nodes. All hardware should be addressed by their subdirectory in /dev which you can see in the output when you type mount.
I used low level R/W with dd and piping to and from netcat, respectively on machine to clone from and machine to clone to, as described in a howto. We clone using convert and copy (dd) and netcat (nc).
On the golden slave (or an identical clone) you run: <source lang="bash"> node1# dd if=/dev/hda conv=sync,noerror bs=64k | nc -l 5000 </source>
On the completely blank soon-to-be-slave you run: <source lang="bash"> node2# nc 192.168.1.1 5000 | dd of=/dev/hda bs=64k </source>
where 192.168.1.1 is the ip of the golden slave. This presupposes the disk of soon-to-be slave is at least as big as the disk in the golden slave.
This took several hours time (it said 158GB read/written), but it worked.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Building a Beowulf Cluster/Installation, Configuration, and Administration/Miscellaneous

revision.comment: /* Kinds of Search */ Fix link for Minimax search
revision.text:
== Introduction ==
The general concept of ‘searching’ is about looking for something. For example, we want to drive to some destination and we need to find the car key. Locating the car key is a simple search problem. In computer science, searching techniques are strategies that look for solutions to a problem in a search space. The solutions or ‘goal states’ could sometimes be an object, a goal, a sub-goal or a path to the searched item. In the car key example, the search goal is the car key and the search space is confined to the owner’s home. The car key can be located anywhere in the owner’s house.
In general, a computer search problem has the following characteristics:
* A goal state – the definition of a need * An initial state – a current position or a set of conditions * A set of actions - strategies and actions to select and evaluate an option in the search space * Goal test criteria – criteria used to test if an option is a solution * A path cost - the cost of the actions in a search path
== Search Space ==
The search space can be represented by a ‘graph’ which is based on graph theory. The ‘graph’ structure is not to be confused with the graphs that the readers might have learned from their regular mathematics courses. A computer ‘tree’ data structure is a special kind of graph. A tree has a root node on the top of the structure and it has at most one path to each node. Each node may be connected to a lower level of neighbors which are called child nodes (successors). Nodes that have no children are called leaf nodes.
Using the car key example, the owner’s home is defined as the search space. It has the ‘home’ node as the root of a tree. The home node has three child nodes (the room nodes) and other child nodes such as desks and drawer in the rooms. The set of possible permutations that can be examined by a search method in order to find a solution.
== Kinds of Search ==
* [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Heuristic search/Astar Search|A* search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Heuristic search/Beam search|Beam search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Heuristic search/Best-first search|Best-first search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Heuristic search/Bidirectional Search|Bidirectional search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Exhaustive search/Breadth-first search|Breadth-first search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Heuristic search/Depth-first search|Depth-first search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Dijkstra's Algorithm|Dijkstra's algorithm]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Exhaustive search/Finite state automata|Finite state automate]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Iterative Improvement/Hill Climbing|Hill climbing]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Adversarial search/Minimax Search|Minimax search]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Recommender Systems|Recommender systems]] * [[Artificial Intelligence/Search/Heuristic search/Tabu Search|Tabu search]]
[[Category:Artificial Intelligence]]

== The Plan ==
The [[Embedded Systems]] book is sprawling and contains a lot of stubs on various topics, some of which are only tangentially related to the topic. I am thinking (but am not yet self-convinced) that this book could be better served if it was broken up into a series of smaller books on more focused topics.

*Three sides to triangle = Completeness - Godhead and Tripod of Education Mental, Physical, and Spiritual
*Shield = protection of God, and by faith
*Red = Sacrifice *White = Purity *Blue = Loyalty *Gold = Excellence

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...c5/2. Nf3/2...Nc6/3. Nc3

revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Sicilian| |rd| |bd|qd|kd|bd|nd|rd|= |pd|pd| |pd|pd|pd|pd|pd|= | | |nd| | | | | |= | | |pd| | | | | |= | | | | |pl| | | |= | | |nl| | |nl| | |= |pl|pl|pl|pl| |pl|pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl| |rl|= || }} ==Sicilian== ==3. Nc3== Most of the time in the Sicilian, White puts his Knight on c3. White may yet play d4, but for the moment the question is yet to be answered. White's second move suggests the possibility of NOT playing d4 (avoiding the exchange), and playing a closed position instead of the slashing, attacking types of position, that are more common to the Sicilian Defence. Leads to 3.g3 g6 4.Bg2 Bg7 5.d3 d6 3...d6 This is the main line and is a non-committal move. Black retains flexibility to wait and see if white opens up the game with d4 or opts to keep it closed such as d3 and maybe c3 to prepare the hallmark d4 push and locking up the center. ==Theory table== {{Chess Opening Theory/Table}}. '''1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Nc3'''
3
Sicilian, Taimanov ...
[[/3...e6|e6]]		 d4
 
Sicilian ...
[[/3...d6|d6]]		 d4
 
{{ChessMid}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Wikipedia|Sicilian Defence}} {{BCO2}} {{Chess Opening Theory/Footer}}

[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Timothypratley!
{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="margin:0em 0em 1em 0em; width:100%" | style="width:45%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #fad67d; background-color:#faf6ed;" |
[[Image:Crystal Clear app korganizer.png|20px]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for freely-licensed collaboratively-developed [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].'''
You don't need technical skills in order to contribute here. '''[[WB:BOLD|Be bold]]''' contributing here and ''[[WB:AGF|assume good faith]]'' for the intentions of others. Remember, this is a ''[[w:wiki|wiki]]'', so you're allowed to change just about anything, and changes can be made easily. Come [[WB:HELP|introduce yourself]] to everyone, and let us know what interests you.
[[Image:Icon apps query.svg|20px]] '''Getting help'''
* Get help from the community in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]] or in our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * We tag pages with various [[WB:TM|message templates]], such as {{tlx|query}}, to let editors know what needs to be improved. To learn more about these, ask at [[WB:PROJECTS|the projects reading room]], or insert {{helpme|your reason here}} * You cannot upload an image until you have been a member for at least '''4 days'''. If your upload is tagged with {{tlx|nld}}, {{tlx|bfu}}, or {{tlx|nfur}}, please read the template message as it explains the violation of [[WB:MEDIA|our media policy]]. Please be sure to provide the required {{tlx|information}}: a [[WB:ICT|license tag]] and source citation are always required; fair use images require a {{tlx|fair use rationale}}. Get help in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]]. | style="padding:0em 0.5em 0em 0.5em;" | | style="width:55%; vertical-align:top; border:1px solid #abd5f5; background-color:#f1f5fc;" |
[[Image:Transmission icon.png|20px]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please [[:w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|sign your name]] on discussion pages by typing ~~~~ * If you're coming here from Wikipedia, you should read [[WB:WFW|our primer for Wikipedians]] to get up-to-speed quickly. * '''Please make sure you follow our [[WB:NP|naming policy]]''' - modules should be named like Book Title/Chapter Title. * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
[[Image:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (only become available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To get a page deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason for requesting deletion''}} to the top of the page. * If something you wrote was deleted, please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:VFD|VFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:VFU]].
Thanks  '''— [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 05:43, 21 November 2008 (UTC)
